SENT.plain: Sphingolipid metabolites are important regulators of cell growth and death
In the present study, we examined the function of cell surface sialic acid in exogenous sphingosine-1-phosphate (S-1-P) or sphingosine-induced cell death
HBL-2 human diffuse large B cell lymphoma cells were incubated with or without Vibrio Cholerae neuraminidase followed by S-1-P or sphingosine

Flow cytometric analysis using Limax flavus agglutinin, a sialic acid-specific lectin, showed that sialylated glycoconjugates are present on the surface of HBL-2 cells and that they were removed by neuraminidase
In addition, the pretreatment with neuraminidase enhanced S-1-P- and sphingosine-induced cell death, an effect that was not dependent on caspase activation
Furthermore, the cell death induced by S-1-P and sphingosine was morphologically distinct from apoptosis
We further examined S-1-P-induced cell death in two clones of HBL-8 Burkitt lymphoma cells with different amounts of cell surface sialic acid
Clone 3G3, which is hypersialylated, was less sensitive to S-1-P than the 3D2 clone, which is hyposialylated, suggesting that the extent of surface sialylation influences the sensitivity to S-1-P
In conclusion, S-1-P and sphingosine induce cell death, and the sensitivity of human B lymphoma cells to these agents appears to depend on the amount of sialic acid on their cell surfaces
